captions.text:
Sharks are really, really cool. They've been
around about 400 million years. There's over

400 species of them, and they even have the
ability to detect electromagnetic fields in

the water. All of which is why it's so baffling
that Discovery Channel's Shark Week has so

little biology in it. Recently, it's become
more like a reality tv show than a series

of nature documentaries. And in the past two
years, it's veered into really weird territory,

with Discovery Channel actually deceiving
viewers about sharks. It wasn't always like

this. Back in 1988 when it started, by all
accounts the shows were great and educational.

But slowly it's become more and more sensational.
In the last few years, most of its shows have

been about Great Whites attacking humans.
Surely there's something thrilling about that.

But there's something backwards about it too.
Shark attacks are really rare. And in truth,

we're a bigger threat to sharks than they
are to us. These shows about shark attacks

are great for making people scared of sharks.
They don't do much for making people care

about them. Now if Shark Week was just sensationalized,
that might be disappointing but tolerable.

But last year, Discovery Channel entered new
territory, completely making up a story. They

aired a documentary with a scientist who told
us that there was a 100-foot shark called

Megalodon roaming the oceans, and it killed
4 people off the coast of South Africa last

year. "Zoom in. Once more. And to the right.
I know it's kind of blurry but look at that. Look at that.

That's a fin!" But here's the thing. The scientist
was an actor, the footage was faked, and the

deaths didn't even happen. Viewers had no
way of knowing this. There was just a disclaimer

saying that the scenes were dramatized. All
shark researchers agree that megalodon went

extinct 2 million years ago, but an online
poll afterwards showed that 73% of viewers thought it was real.

This was the highest
rated episode in Shark Week history, which

is probably why Discovery is doubling down
with fake shark programming this year. First,

in a promo, they hoaxed viewers by claiming
there was a shark in Lake Ontario, which they

had to admit was fake after Canadian officials
believed it and started getting worried. Then

they kicked things off with a new fake documentary,
Shark of Darkness, about a non-existant 35-foot

white shark. "What made this incident particularly
horrifying was that the attacks were captured

on camera." Featuring another fake scientist
from a fake research institute, blaming a

fake shark for a death that didn't happen.
Finally, they're following up with a megalodon

sequel that claims to have new evidence. The
worst part about all of this? Discovery viewers

have a real appetite for actual science. When
the channel debuted BBC's series, Life, it

got over 11 million viewers, more than twice
as many as megalodon. Discovery calls itself

the world's #1 nonfiction media company. But
it's apparently decided that the natural world
isn't interesting enough for TV.

title: Does Megalodon still exist? Shark Week debunked

comments.author: Jaydin Placeres

comments.text:
Just so everyone is aware, the so called "documentary" was clearly called a 
mockumentary, which was clearly stated on the discovery channel website 
when they first posted information on the special. Meaning that it was fake 
from the get go, and strictly for entertainment. Of course most, if not 
all, of the information given was fake. The reason they did not post a 
proper disclaimer was to get the same effect as the Mermaid the Body 
Found mockumentary did. It got people talking about the possible existence 
of these unknown, or thought to be extinct, creatures. If anything it gets 
people interested in marine life. If you are the kind of person who is able 
to take something that is obviously fake and think it is real than you are 
an idiot. Is shark week all just great white attacks? No, but yes they have 
a lot of it because it brings in ratings. Ratings are the life blood of any 
network. Its simple business.﻿

comments.author: London Casper

comments.text:
Discovery is absolutely putrid these days. It's all sensationalism and 
reality tv (really, that's most American tv, but I digress). It's a shame, 
because I really do want to watch shows about gold mining and prospecting, 
and sharks, and nature shows, and survival tips - on paper, that all sounds 
great to me - but not when it's all fake, over-edited and over-dramatized 
bullshit. And then the complete dishonesty and lack of integrity involved 
with these "documentaries" they parade around as the real deal. It's 
disgusting. Honestly I don't even watch tv anymore, and it's because of 
stuff like this. Especially when there are other places I can go, like here 
at Youtube, where there are several channels pumping out entertaining, 
educational, and fact based content that I can watch instead (there are bad 
channels too, but that's the beauty part of it, you get to pick and choose 
from basically any type of content you want). Nevermind the money I save 
not paying for cable. I just want to watch something and not feel like I'm 
being talked down to like a fucking idiot.﻿

technology at our disposal finding these LOST CREATURES should by 
relatively easy. IF THEY STILL EXIST AT ALL? I like to watch or view 
SCIENTIFIC-FACT not HOLLYWOOD-FAKE!!!﻿

Until 2012 the Pygmy Right Whale had been thought to have been extinct for

comments.author: Chad Rushing

comments.text:
No, it makes them look like good scientists. They had no reason to belive 
the Pygmy Right Whale was still alive, so they didn´t. Now they have.

Megalodon still existing.
